content: Question - should I uninstall Thunderbird and try to reinstall it and see if that would make a difference? Can I do that and have my settings and folders remain as they are or would I have to start from scratch??
creator: pegp

content:
What is the size of your Inbox?

What is your anti-virus software?

Also, please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.

should I uninstall Thunderbird and try to reinstall it and see if that would make a difference?

You'd be wasting your time. All your data such as messages, passwords and user preferences, and changes made while you use Thunderbird, are stored in a special folder called a profile. Your profile folder is stored in a separate place from the Thunderbird program, so that if something ever goes wrong with Thunderbird your information will still be there. It also means that you can uninstall Thunderbird and reinstall without losing your settings and data. But you don't need to do that in order to troubleshoot a problem.

creator: mozilla98

content:
From another thread (would you please keep comments in the same thread?):

cj69again said
To Scooter. The statements were on different days/times. I can live with this. I think when there were several emails sent from my phone, it was quite a long time on that occasion until they eventually did display in the Thunderbird sent folder. I think I will now review my home sync, and WiFi details etc, so I will shortly close my query. Just before I do this closure, it would be helpful to understand why you asked "if it was a Microsoft account" to which I said "no it's a Gmail address" - is that a possible factor in all of this?

If you are using your Gmail account everywhere, then my inquiry is not relevant. But Gmail could have some quirks that I don't know about because I do not use Gmail.

In any case, I asked about a Microsoft account because I imagined that Microsoft's use of folders for sent messages that are different from sent folders on IMAP accounts could cause your symptoms. When I had a Microsoft account that I accessed from two e-mail clients on my computer and one on my phone, it was easy to end up with copies of sent messages in zero folders or two folders. Some trials and errors were needed to get all sent messages saved in one folder. One has to be careful about the options in account settings > copies & folders. Sent messages could also be saved in a folder that you are not seeing because you didn't know about it and did not subscribe to it.

If your problem is not really solved after the review that plan to do, please start a new thread and post all the information that might be helpful to other problem-solvers on the forum.

Good luck.

content:
I don't know what is causing this problem.

Are you certain that there is no auto-reply at the server? (That is a usually a better place to put one than in an e-mail client.)

I can only guess that the file system is out of sync with the settings in the user interface. Message filters are stored in a file called "msgFilterRules.dat" in your profile. On my installation, that file is in ImapMail.[service provider's domain]. If you are willing to lose all your filters, you could close Thunderbird and delete that file. I have not done this. I have read that it is probably safe. I expect that Thunderbird will create the file when you create another filter. That is a guess.

Sometimes anti-virus software interferes with storing and updating settings in the file system. Maybe extensions too, I don't know. Are you using anti-virus software or extensions?

A non-destructive work-around might be to delete the template that you use for your auto-reply message. If there is nothing to send, maybe Thunderbird won't send anything. You could test that easily.
creator: mozilla98

content:

creator: ryan14

content:
You deleted the template but messages still get created with that template?!

Re-start Thunderbird and test it again.

Are you certain that the auto-reply is not coming from the server? Thunderbird now has no template to send and the filter log is not showing that a filter even runs. The evidence suggests that your problem lies elsewhere.

The only other possible explanation I have is that something is interfering with changes to files in the file system. You did not answer my question about anti-virus software and add-ons. Try this:

  • Start your computer in safe mode.
  • Start Thunderbird in safe mode. "Help" menu > "Troubleshoot mode..."
  • Send yourself a test message.
  • What happens?

To delete the file that holds the message filters:

  1. In Thunderbird, "Help" menu > "Troubleshooting information" > "about:profiles".
  2. Find your active folder. In its "root directory" row, click on "Show in [...]".
  3. Find and open the ImapMail folder.
  4. Find and open the folder in ImapMail for the account in question.
  5. Find the msgFilterRules.dat file.
  6. Make a copy of the file on your desktop in case you need it later.
  7. Delete msgFilterRules.dat from your profile.
  8. Re-start Thunderbird.

This forum is the only place where support is provided. You can file a bug report here: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/enter_bug.cgi?product=Thunderbird

I am not convinced that there is a bug (yet).

I will see if others can help here.

creator: sfhowes

content:
(I'm making the assumption that you have already gone to the Account Settings and removed the problem account.)

So, there are 3 things you need to check:

1. Your calendars - do you still have a calendar connected to your removed account? 2. Your address books - do you have an address book connected to your removed account? 3. Your SMTP settings - Under "Account Settings" > "Outgoing Server (SMTP)", do you still have an identity listed from your removed account?

If any of those are still present, they need to be removed.

You can further debug this problem by:

Check if addons are the problem

1. Go to "Help" > "Troubleshoot mode". 2. Click "Okay" or whatever the button is to continue and restart Thunderbird. 3. After Thunderbird opens, wait to see if you get the popup again. 4. If you do, then addons are NOT the cause.

Look at the raw settings file

1. Go to "Help" > "Troubleshooting information". 2. Check "Include account names" at the top. 3. See if your removed account still shows up. (You can use CTRL + F to search this page)

If it is not listed, that doesn't mean it's totally gone. To be absolutely sure you can:

1. Click "Open Directory" to the right of "Profile Directory". 2. Close Thunderbird. 3. In that directory you opened, open pref.js. 4. If Thunderbird references your removed account at all, it will be in this file.

This will point you in the right direction. I don't think I would recommend updating pref.js. Maybe if you go to "about:config" instead and update any settings from there, it would be safer. Also - Do not update "pref.js" while Thunderbird is open, your changes will get overwritten when Thunderbird closes.
